title: Win9x Ring0 Quest Part I
historical_context: This article is part of a series exploring techniques to gain ring0 access on the Windows 9x platform, a topic of significant interest during the late 1990s as Windows 9x was widely used and less secure than its successors.
target_audience: Hackers, security researchers, and malware developers interested in low-level Windows programming and exploitation techniques.
short_summary: This article discusses various techniques for obtaining ring0 access on the Windows 9x platform, including methods for detecting the OS version and exploiting system calls. It provides code examples and explanations aimed at helping readers understand the underlying mechanisms.
summary:
In 'Win9x Ring0 Quest Part I', Super/29A delves into the intricacies of achieving ring0 access on the Windows 9x operating system. The article outlines several methods for detecting whether the system is running Windows 9x or Windows NT, emphasizing the importance of this distinction for exploitation techniques. The author presents a variety of approaches, including the use of APIs like GetVersion and GetVersionExA, as well as examining the structure of the kernel and the behavior of system calls. Each method is accompanied by code snippets that readers can compile and test, making the article both informative and practical for those looking to enhance their skills in low-level Windows programming.

The article serves as a foundational piece for understanding how to manipulate the Windows 9x environment to gain elevated privileges. It discusses the use of CallGates, IntGates, and ExceptionGates to transition from user mode to kernel mode, providing detailed explanations of how these mechanisms work. The author encourages readers to experiment with the provided code and to contribute their own findings, fostering a collaborative spirit within the hacking community. Overall, this article is a valuable resource for anyone interested in the technical aspects of operating system security and exploitation.
